ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to calculate values necessary for relating planets and stars to each other.
Expanded knowledge of the way space works, in ways that directly affect my daily life and in ways that won't affect humans for millenia.

I learnt a lot about the formation and evolution of stars and planets, along with how to measure their properties and the distance to them etc. I learnt a lot about the history of our galaxy & universe and the history & people behind certain discoveries. I think this is a really good baseline for astronomy classes, and I would feel very confident going into another one after this.
How astronomers know certain things about the universe, some observing skills.
Different skills of how astronomers know what they know about the universe and basic history/knowledge of astronomy.

How astronomers calculate between angular size, diameter, and distance. Stars' and planets' formation. The Solar System. Mathematical relationships like wavelength radiated and velocity, stars' luminosity and brightness and temperature, gravitational force and mass, binary stars' masses, orbital period and semimajor axis of orbit.

This is really good introduction to astronomy! I learned how to extract different information from just looking about the stars in the sky and how we are able to measure many different properties of stars even though they are so far away.
Formation of planets and stars, how to identify planets and stars, tools to measure data about planets and stars

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A strength was that it allowed us to apply mathematical concepts to our understanding of the universe.
I found the lectures and material quite interesting, the weakness would be that there were lots and lots of videos and reading, maybe one or the other should be cut down.

Strengths - the professor is great, and clearly cares a lot about the subject and their students. He did a great job of answering every one of the students' questions. The way we worked through the course material made sense. It operates as a flipped classroom, which can be a strength or a weakness, but I personally liked that the meeting times were more informal and discussion based, and that I got to watch the lectures at my leisure.

Weaknesses - the classes, discussion sections, and both exams were all at the same time of day. This was obviously a strength if you value consistency, but since this time was relatively late in the day sometimes I think it would've been better to change the timings, especially as the exams were on a Sunday. The psets were very long and it would have been nice to have the slides from the lectures.
I enjoyed the discussion nature of the class.  It was also very clear what we had to know for the course exams and psets.  The observing exercise was fun.  Garrett was a great teaching fellow.
I thought that the information was taught in a way that made it interesting but discussion groups over zoom sometimes felt less helpful than just having lectures and asking questions.

Prerecorded lecture videos were very informative but long and their main points were not the same as those in the psets and exams. Feedback and expectations on psets and exams are not very clear. It is good that Dr. Faison provides time during class to ask him questions about concepts that we don't understand, but he dislikes questions about homework and exams. His classes and lectures are interesting though. He likes to share current astronomy news.

The professor is really great. You can tell he cares a lot about the course. Overall, the course is really good; I really enjoy the flipped classroom structure because it lets me watch lecture on my own time and then work on practice problems and clarify things I probably wouldn't have asked during class time. The only critique I have is on the quiz questions during recorded lectures. Some of the questions weren't very well defined; I wasn't always sure what exactly they were asking. The quiz questions were pretty much just graded for completion, though, so that made it more okay and less stressful about getting some of them wrong. Again, though, this is a great course overall.
Loved the interactive discussion sections.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would. Its a great way to get a science credit!
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone wanting to know more about stars and planets, it's a really great introductory course if you have an interest!
I would definitely recommend this course to someone looking for an accessible science credit who is interested in astronomy.  The course was low stress but I learned a lot.
Yes, it is a great science class for non stem majors. Not too easy but also not overwhelming and the content is interesting.
Yes if you're interested in astronomy but do not plan to major in it.
Yes, absolutely!
Yes!
